docs.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE - Neither John McCain nor Barack Obama provided enough direct answers or personal, emotive moments during Tuesday night's debate, according to three audience members who posed questions to them, though Mr. Obama won quite a bit of goodwill by staying afterward to shake hands and sign autographs while Mr. McCain left.

headline.main: Debate Audience Members Talk About Candidates

docs.abstract: A few members of the Belmont University audience in Nashville said they were surprised that McCain left so quickly after the debate.
docs.snippet: A few members of the Belmont University audience in Nashville said they were surprised that McCain left so quickly after the debate.

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after Richard S. Fuld Jr. was compelled to explain the millions of dollars he made at Lehman Brothers, two former executives of the American International Group took their turns in government witness chairs on Tuesday, answering critical questions from lawmakers about business and pay practices and outsize spending that continued even after the company received an $85 billion lifeline from the government.

headline.main: A.I.G. Takes Its Turn in Hot Seat

docs.lead_paragraph: The drug maker manipulated the publication of studies to bolster use of its epilepsy drug Neurontin, according to expert witnesses in a lawsuit against the company.

headline.sub: An Epilepsy Drug Known for Off-Label Uses;

docs.snippet: The drug maker manipulated the publication of studies to bolster use of its epilepsy drug Neurontin, according to expert witnesses in a lawsuit against the company.

docs.lead_paragraph: At a hearing on compensation and spending at A.I.G, one lawmaker criticized the “unbridled greed” of executives.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and SHARON OTTERMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: In their second debate, Senators Barack Obama and John McCain indulged in their fair share of misrepresentations on Tuesday night as they tried to convince voters of their fitness to be president. Here are some of their misstatements: Big Spender

headline.main: On a Variety of Topics, Room for Exaggerations

docs.abstract: Sens Barack Obama and John McCain make misrepresentations on variety of topics during their second presidential debate; both mischaracterize elements of their opponent's health care proposals and may have oversold their own; neither is clear on whether he would go into Pakistan to pursue insurgents attacking American forces in Afghanistan; Obama makes vague assertions about policy and history on subject of humanitarian intervention to prevent genocide; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In their second debate, Senators Barack Obama and John McCain indulged in their fair share of misrepresentations on Tuesday night as they tried to convince voters of their fitness to be president. Here are some of their misstatements:     Big Spender
